[[Faring Forth#Other versions of the legendarium|Second Faring Forth]] }} '''Luthany''' was located in the [[Great Lands]], and afterwards it became the island of [[wikipedia:Great Britain|Great Britain]], according to the early version of the [[legendarium]] in some of the outlines for the continuation of ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''. == History == === Origin === Luthany was originally connected to the [[Great Lands]],{{LT2|VI}}, p. 308 and after the [[First Faring Forth]] and the war with evil [[Men]] the [[Elves]] that yet remained in the Great Lands moved to Luthany in large numbers due to the fact that the King of Luthany was [[Ing]], a Man that was friendly towards the Elves.{{LT2|VI}}, outlines '''18''' and '''20''', pp. 302/3, 304 === Eärendel and Ing === At some point in time [[Eärendel]], fleeing from [[Ossë]], appeared in Luthany and sought Ing's help. In return, Eärendel gave Ing ''[[limpë]]'', a drink that turned him immortal.In another outline, it was the Elves living in Luthany who gave Ing ''limpë'', with Eärendel coming to Luthany after the invasion of the [[Rúmhoth]] has already taken place. He also blessed Ing's progeny, and told him of [[Tol Eressëa]], an island to which the Elves of Luthany go to, kindling Ing's desire to sail there. Presumably due to this, Ing and many of his people embarked on a voyage to Tol Eressëa - however, due to Ossë's wrath at Ing's helping of Eärendel, they were caught up in a storm and blown eastwards, with Ing being the only survivor.{{LT2|VI}}, outlines '''23''' and '''24''', p. 306 In response to the departure of Ing, and in fear of an invasion by evil Men, the Elves of Luthany cut a [[wikipedia:English channel|channel]] that separated Luthany from the rest of the Great Lands, making it an island.{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''26''', p. 307 The island of Luthany suffered seven invasions in its history after the arrival of the Elves, each one worse for the Elves than the last one. The penultimate invasion was that of the [[Rúmhoth]] (also known as the [[wikipedia:Romans|Romans]]) who did not even believe that the Elves were real, prompting the departure of nearly every elf left on the island. === England's origins === After 300 years however the [[Ingwaiwar]] (people of Ing) invaded and were friendly to the Elves due to the teachings of Ing - and because of this, what little was left of the Elves on the island temporarily slowed down their exodus to Tol Eressëa, many of whom learned [[Old English]], the language of the Ingwaiwar, during that time.{{LT2|VI}}, outlines '''19''' and '''20''', p. 304 Some time after, a mariner called [[Ælfwine]], a descendant of Ing, was born in Luthany. He would later manage to find a way to Tol Eressëa, and learn the histories of the Elves. In one of the outlines of the ''Book of Lost Tales'', Ælfwine was the author of the ''[[Parma Kuluina|Golden Book of Tavrobel]]''.{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''30''', p. 310 According to another outline, it was prophesied by the Elves that Ing would eventually lead them from Tol Eressëa back to Luthany{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''22''', pp. 305-6 in the [[Second Faring Forth]].{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''27''', p. 307 == Description == Many of the places in Tol Eressëa, such as [[Kortirion]] or [[Tavrobel]] (the New), were named after older places in Luthany (such as [[Kortirion the Old]] or [[Tavrobel the Old]]).{{LT2|VI}}, outlines '''29''' and '''30''', p. 310 == Etymology == The name ''Luthany'' is in [[Gnomish]],{{webcite|author=[[Paul Strack]]|articleurl=http://eldamo.org/content/words/word-3982558599.html|articlename=G. ''Luthany'' loc.|website=Eldamo|accessed=14 April 2022}} meaning "friendship".{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''19''', p. 304 '''''Albion''''' also appears as a name of Luthany in one of the outlines.{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''20''', p. 304 An earlier form of the name was '''''Lúthien''''' (in most other texts from this time period its meaning is "friend", appearing in conjunction with ''Luthany'' = "friendship"). An alternative form, '''''Leithian''''', appears written above ''Lúthien'' in one of the texts.{{LT2|VI}}, note 20, pp. 329-330 == Other versions of the legendarium == {{expansion}} In a somewhat later version of the [[legendarium]] from the [[1930]] (''[[Quenta Noldorinwa]]''), '''Leithien''' was the name of one of the islands that were formed during the destruction of [[Beleriand]] in the [[War of Wrath]]. It later became known as Britain or England.{{SM|Q18II}}, p. 162 == Inspiration == ''Luthany'' appears as a name of a country in a poem called ''The Mistress of Vision'' by [[wikipedia:Francis Thompson|Francis Thompson]], who was an influence on [[Tolkien]].{{LT2|VI}}, note 14, pp. 328-9 {{references|notes}} [[Category:Gnomish locations]] [[Category:Great Lands]] [[Category:Islands]] [[Category:Locations in The Book of Lost Tales]] [[Category:Luthany| ]]
